_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary :



The Matheson Tri-Gas facility is located at 6775 Central Avenue in Newark, California, which is approximately 1.1 miles southwest of Interstate 880.  The facility stores cylinders of compressed specialty/industrial gas in both large and small quantities. The cylinders vary from 2000 pounds to less than 1 pound of gas depending on the  of the cylinder and the type of chemical packaged.



Note:  This October 2013 update of the RMP was prepared to address the addition of new storage processes and the removal of the boron trichloride and chlorine purification processes.  The boron trichloride and chlorine purification processes have been decommissioned and are no longer used at the facility.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Matheson Tri-Gas is committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment and the procedures necessary to prevent accidental releases of chemicals. In addition we are committed to developing and maintaining the manpower, the equipment and the emergency response procedures necessary to mitigate a release quickly and effectively if it does occur. Employees and management meet regularly to discuss ongoing operations, potential problems, and continuous improvements to prevent releases from occurring. Trained emergency response personnel will respond immediately to any release or potential release, evaluate the situation, and determine the need to call outside emergency responders.  



Regulated Chemicals and Processes



There are 7 chemicals in 12 processes at the Matheson Tri-Gas Newark facility that are regulated under the Federal RMP Program. The detailed applicability of all inventory levels is listed in the on-site California RMP (Cal-ARP) documentation. The processes regulated by Federal RMP regulations can be summarized as follows:

  

Chemical ------ Process



Ammonia ------ Bldg 7 NH3 Storage

Ammonia ------ Bldg 5 NH3 Storage

Ammonia ------ Area 4 NH3 Storage

Arsine

----- Bldg 7 AsH3 Cylinder Storage

Arsine ----- Bldg 5 AsH3 Cylinder Storage

Chlorine ------ Bldg 7 CL2 Cylinder Storage

Chlorine ------ Area 4 Cylinder Storage

Hydrogen Chloride ------ Bldg 7 HCl Cylinder Storage

Hydrogen Chloride ------ Bldg 5 HCl Cylinder Storage

Hydrogen Fluoride ------ Bldg 7 HF Cylinder Storage

Sulfur Dioxide ------ Bldg 7 SO2 Cylinder Storage

Trichlorosilane ------ Bldg 7 HSiCl3 Cylinder Storage



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Mitigation Measures



The major elements of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and release mitigation measures at this site are as follows:  



Life safety system.  A state-of-the-art life safety system was installed in late 1999 and early 2000.  This system monitors the presence of various toxic and flammable gases in areas where those gases are stored or processed.  Two-stage alarms are set for each sensor.  The low-level alarm alerts the facility that a problem may be developing.  The high-level alarm provides notification to the Fire Department as well as to the facility.  The system provides real time readouts of gas concentrations and records information that assists in both preventing and mitigating gas releases as well as information that can assist in improving the process.  



Adherence to objective equipment standards.  One of the most significant contributors to the prevention of accidental releases at this site is the high standards to which all gas cylinders must be manufactured.  The Department of Transportation (DOT) has detailed requirements for manufacturing and testing cylinders. Cylinders must be manufactured according to a particular metallurgical standard and be able to withstand overfilling; an increase in pressure; an increase in temperature and the possibility that they will be hit or fall over.     



Process hazard analysis.  Process hazard analyses are performed on relevant processes to determine potential hazards and recommendations for process improvements.

Development and implementation of standard operating procedures.  There is a system established for creating and maintaining operating procedures.



A comprehensive training program that includes classroom and on-the-job training. Training has been established for new and existing employees such that safety in operations is maintained.



A systematic preventive maintenance program.  All relevant equipment is on a schedule for inspection; inspections are documented and certain equipment is replaced on a regular schedule. 



A thorough accident reporting and investigation program.  The accident/incident reporting and investigation procedure requires the reporting and investigation not only of incidents resulting in injuries, but also incidents that had the potential to result in an injury to an employee or a significant impact on the company's business. 



Restricted access. There are a series of internal and external electronic gates that restrict access into the facility. There are personel on-site 24/7/365 to inspect and safeguard all equipment and storage. Motion detectors and facility cameras are available for recording activity through the plant.



Five-Year Accident History 



EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.  The release must have caused at least one of the following:

?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



A review of the facility's accident history revealed that the facility had one RMP reportable incident in the last five years (October 2008 - October 2013).  The incident occurred on September 10, 2010, during the de-valving of a faulty ammonia cylinder valve.  An employee in the area during the incident was provided with precautionary tr

eatment for ammonia inhalation.  The facility contacted the fire department and the California Emergency Management Agency and notified them of the release.  An incident investigation was conducted and corrective actions were made to prevent the incident from re-occurring.



Emergency Response Program



All hazardous material have been identified, located and mapped. A cylinder storage procedure maintains consistent locations for each material.  Any changes in chemical storage locations are documented annually with the County of Alameda Department of Environmental Health in the facility's Hazardous Materials Business Plan.



ERT members must go through refresher training every year. At least four responders are always available at all times. Appropriate personal protective equipment is maintained at the site for response actions. 



Evacuation routes and procedures have been developed and all personnel are trained in the procedures. The Emergency Response Contact List is maintained and all personnel are trained on the portions relevant to their job.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Matheson Tri-Gas has made enhancements to improve safety at the facility.  These enhancements include the discontinuation of the processing of toxic and corrosive gases.  This reduces the risks of an accidental release at the facility.
